Consts.useLimit:
ArcGIS for Desktop Basic: Requires Spatial Analyst

ArcGIS for Desktop Standard: Requires Spatial Analyst

ArcGIS for Desktop Advanced: Requires Spatial Analyst

dataIdInfo.idAbs: Calculates cross-tabulated areas between two datasets and outputs a table. Supports overlapping feature zone data, non overlapping zone data and raster zone data.

tool.name: TabulateArea02

param.name: in_zone_data
param.displayname: Input raster or feature zone data
param.dialogReference:
Dataset that defines the zones.

The zones can be defined by an integer raster or a feature layer.
param.pythonReference:
Dataset that defines the zones.

The zones can be defined by an integer raster or a feature layer.

param.name: zone_field
param.dialogReference:
Field that holds the values that define each zone.

It can be an integer or a string field of the zone dataset.
param.pythonReference:
Field that holds the values that define each zone.

It can be an integer or a string field of the zone dataset.

param.name: in_class_data
param.displayname: Input raster or feature class data
param.dialogReference:
The dataset that defines the classes that will have their area summarized within each zone.

The class input can be an integer raster layer or a feature layer.
param.pythonReference:
The dataset that defines the classes that will have their area summarized within each zone.

The class input can be an integer raster layer or a feature layer.

param.name: class_field
param.dialogReference:
The field that holds the class values.

It can be an integer or a string field of the input class data.
param.pythonReference:
The field that holds the class values.

It can be an integer or a string field of the input class data.

param.name: out_table
param.dialogReference: Output table that will contain the summary of the area of each class in each zone.
param.pythonReference: Output table that will contain the summary of the area of each class in each zone.

param.name: cell_size
param.dialogReference:
The processing cell size for the zonal operation.

This is the value in the environment if specifically set. If the environment is not set, the default for the cell size is determined by the type of the zone data as follows:

  • If the zone dataset is a raster, the cell size is the same as the zone raster.

  • If the zone dataset is a feature, the cell size is the shorter of the width or height of the extent of the zone feature dataset in the output spatial reference, divided by 250.
param.pythonReference:
The processing cell size for the zonal operation.

This is the value in the environment if specifically set. If the environment is not set, the default for the cell size is determined by the type of the zone data as follows:

  • If the zone dataset is a raster, the cell size is the same as the zone raster.

  • If the zone dataset is a feature, the cell size is the shorter of the width or height of the extent of the zone feature dataset in the output spatial reference, divided by 250.

tool.usage:
• A zone is defined as all areas in the input that have the same value. The areas do not have to be contiguous. Both raster and feature datasets can be used for the zone input.

  • When the zone and class inputs are both rasters of the same resolution, they will be used directly.

    If the resolutions are different, an internal resampling is applied to make them match before the zonal operation is performed.

  • If the zone input is a raster dataset, it must have an attribute table. The attribute table is usually created automatically for integer rasters, but may not be under certain circumstances. You can use Build Raster Attribute Table to create one.

  • If the zone input is feature dataset, a vector-to-raster conversion will be internally applied to it.

    To ensure that the results of the conversion will align properly with a class raster input, it is recommended that you check that the extent and snap raster are set appropriately in the environment settings and the raster settings.

  • When specifying the input zone or class data, the default field will be the first available valid field. If no other valid fields exist, the ObjectID field (for example, OID or FID) will be the default.

  • If a reserved field (for example, OBECTID, FID, or OID) is selected for the Zone field, then this may cause some ambiguity in the result. The result includes the particular reserved field name necessary for the particular output format type, as well as the Zone field specified. If the specified field has the same name as the reserved field for the particular output format, in the output the name for the zone field will be altered in such a way that all field names in the result are unique.

    To make a field of unique values that does not have a reserved name, use the Add Fieldand Calculate Fieldgeoprocessing tools

  • If the class input is feature dataset, a vector-to-raster conversion will also be internally applied to it. The conditions listed in the previous tip for a feature zone input also apply to a feature class input.

  • If a point or line dataset is used as the class data, the area intersected by those features will be reported.

  • The output of the Tabulate Area tool is a table.

    In this table:

    • There will be a record for each unique value of the zone dataset.

    • There will be a field for each unique value of the class dataset.

    • Each record will store the area of each class within each zone.

  • See Working with Tabulate Area for explanations of certain issues that may be encountered with this tool and suggestions on how to work around them.
tool.summary: Calculates cross-tabulated areas between two datasets and outputs a table. Supports overlapping feature zone data, non overlapping zone data and raster zone data.

scriptExample.code: import arcpy from arcpy.env import env env.workspace = "C:/sapyexamples/data" arcpy.AddToolbox(r"C:\pythontoolbox\Spatial Analyst Supplemental Tools.pyt") arcpy.TabulateArea02_sas("buffer_locs","OBJECTID", "slopeRaster", "Value", "c:\sapyexamples\output\fgdb.gdb\tarea_slope",1)
scriptExample.title: Tabulate Area 2, example 1 (Python window)
scriptExample.para: This example calculates area of each slope for buffered locations (that overlap).
